Early Access Review

Since no one else is jumping to review this game, i suppose I will. It's solid. It's not the best and it clearly needs some work, primarily in the graphical portions of the game (water clips through ships and the waves can be higher than towns sometimes. It's odd watching a wall of water pass through your ship without the ship reacting to it). Gameplay on the other hand is very similar to games like Sid Meier's Pirates or Windward just with more focus on questing and you sailing back and forth throughout the world for reasons I'll not spoil here. There is a heavy focus on Sea Combat so you won't have any boarding actions or land battles like in Sid Meier's Pirates. You sail the boat using WASD and your cannons are fired automatically. Basically, you have a certain firing arc on your ship which you need to keep on the enemy ship and then they will fire after a few seconds. Theoretically, you could fire both sides of your ship as long as you keep both within the firing arc. So gameplay is pretty simple from what I've seen so far.
You've also got some pretty intense customization in the game and as you pick up bigger and better ships, you'll also be able to get more things to customize your ship with (Flags, Sail colors/designs, hull designs or color patterns etc). Your crew can also get injured and gain experience which affects the efficiency of your ship and how you perform in combat. You can hire new crewman by sailing into port, going to a tavern" and dragging them onto your ship for a nominal fee. It's all pretty standard stuff for the "Pirate" Genre but it does do some pretty cool things with passive bonuses (Artifacts

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tempest is an open world Pirate/ Naval combat game with elements of grand strategy.  With a good blend of minimalism in focusing on simple pirate combat, combined with the details of a 4X strategy game; Tempest delivers that happy high-seas adventuring every land-lubber dreams about.

“A Very Ancient, and Fish-like Smell:”
With trade routes to plunder, slave ships to chase down, coastal factions to ally, and some common mythological elements to battle, such as sea monsters and the kraken; you’ve got more narrative than just pirates.  Through the missions, story and mystery unfolds. Not to provide a spoiler, but the act of making alliances will cause certain events to take place later in the story. The Lion’s Shade dev team seems to be putting out updates weekly, if not more often. So, I suspect it won’t see a long wait for release. But, early access does not mean a game is less fun to read about and play. Although most games are built on a mechanic that needs to be finished before its fun, there are numerous games like Tempest that deliver a fully built mechanic that will provide hours of fun and excitement in early access.

Artwork & Graphics:
The art is lovely. Those storm-wracked seas provide a magnificent backdrop for hours of gameplay on end. No cards yet, but you can look for some fantastic artwork from this game. An art book would be a welcome addition, as well as full screen backgrounds. The player chooses a banner to display, depending on faction alliances. With the dynamic weather, the beauty of the map motif, and the colorful graphic representations of faction flag and symbols; the game immerses you in an era in naval history that is legend.
Tempest has some errors & bugs, with occasional splicing of elements and waves, & wall glitches, but none of these seem to affect the enjoyment I get from losing everything I had acquired to this gigantic sea monster that appears out of the depths. As Shakespeare said in The Tempest, “He that dies pays all debts.” Losing everything in such a manner is incredibly nice, and 10 times out of 10, I would lose it all again when the game is fully released, with as much pleasure.

Diving into the Mechanics:
The game is played with the open ocean as the predominant view. Here in the 3D view you can spend as much of your time as you like in actual combat. Clicking the map button brings up a map overlay that is a fully functional navigation system. Your ship appears in miniature replica sailing across the map between various settlements. You set waypoints on this view for your ship to travel freely around the map. Interestingly, you can draw out the shape of the exact path you want the ship to take around obstacles. As you watch the ship sail, notifications pop up when you are encountering pirate raids, naval battles, merchant ships and the like. You can choose to click to the ocean view to engage those vessels in combat, or allow the AI to flee the encounter.
When you reach your destination icon on the map, you are switched to the ocean view at the port. There doesn’t seem to be much difference between the map view and the sea. It is like being on the ship looking up from the map on the captain’s table as a ship fires cannonballs at you. In some of the more dangerous harbors, I found myself knocked out of the crew screens by an attack from pirate ships near me. I had been fighting an intense mission, and had several injured crewmen, so I was trying to find meds in port, but kept being attacked while looking for them. I soon realized I needed to travel to a safer port to go shopping lol. And, ports carry a different selection of goods anyways.
Maneuverability is well-thought out. Setting the sails at half-mast (50%) will boost the ship’s maneuverability. Arrow keys control the camera, as well as a right click & drag with the mouse. The camera is fully functional 360 degree rotation on every axis. Zoom works with the mouse scroll-wheel. Compass cardinal directions are visible on the horizon as well, aiding in navigation. It’s quite realistic like being at sea with the captain’s tools in hand, and yet it draws to mind the look of 17th & 18th century maps & ships, like reliving the adventure of the Golden Age of Piracy.
The drag & drop interface is touchscreen friendly with standard WASD keyboard shortcuts, movement around the ocean is possible by using the left mouse button to click and set waypoints, just like on the map.

Sea Battles:
Your ship has a cone-shaped attack zone. The angle depends on the chosen accuracy mode. You can increase the angle with the Q & E keys. The attack zone lights up when you have an enemy in your line of sight. Fire when ready. It is entirely possible to turn on automatic firing in the settings. This causes your cannons to fire when anything comes in your attack zone.  The combat is what the game does best. The look of the battle scenes is reminiscent of the old BBC Admiral Hornblower series.

Alliances & Factions:
You are building a reputation at sea which varies after each battle. The game provides a variety of factions which figure into the missions. I noticed a few errors, like the Foggy Harbor mission sends you to Foggy Harbor, labeled Misty Harbour on the map.

A Motley Crew:
You want a high level crew. You train them with experience points earned in battle by clicking on an arrow button next to each sailor. Rank appears to move from left to right on the boat decks, from Greenhand to Pirate in 5 different classes. A simple click & drag of the screen to the left will reveal the Tavern where you can hire additional crewmen. But, if you already have a full crew, you will have to put some Greenhands on shore leave to hire more experienced hands, just by dragging and dropping them into the Tavern. Of course, the Greenhands are always free if you’re broke. To add an officer to your crew, click on an icon on the left and choose any officer from the list below. You collect these officers from various missions, so you’ll have none at first.

Trading, Goods, & Your Ship:
First things last. :D Yes, every sailor worth his salt had to start out nowhere. You begin Tempest as a poor scoundrel with a bare bones ship and little options for upgrading. So, you’ll want to just have a look around at all the finery you don’t have, before heading out to sea to sink a few ships and claim your first prize money. Then you will be ready to buy some of those red-hot cannon balls and an accurate pistol to board future ships, and perhaps a trusty spyglass. Buy ship parts and upgrade them in port. Here you can focus on Sail, Boarding, or Gunnery efficiency. Dragging the screen to the right while in Goods mode will reveal the warehouse where you can store unused goods until you need them.

Multiplayer:
In the middle of a battle a mysterious ship on fire sailed up near me and began to lob cannon grenades into the air. His ship would glow with a strange blue artifact as well. He was bearing the skull & crossbones so we were allied instantly. I just tried to pick off the smaller ships around while coveting the firepower of this grand ally. But, the MP is the same map as single-player, with other players joining you at will & appearing on your map and in the sea near you, if they are logged in at the same time as you.

Pros:
Combat to satisfy your inner pirate
Ship Navigation system that is fluid & fun
Dynamic Weather & day/night cycle

Cons:
No cards or achievements yet
Early Access
Incomplete Tutorial


I recommend Tempest for all lovers of adventure on the high-seas, and pirates-at-heart. If you enjoy sea battles and navigation, then this game has all that plus sea monsters to die for. I rate Tempest a 10 out of 10 for combat games in the genre.

Tempest:
~~~~~~~

Being a pirate can have its ups and downs, you know! For you it will start on the 26th October 1743 when you lose your ship “The Genriett” to a brutal and mysterious creature after an epic sea battle. Doesn’t sound like you and your crew will start on a high, but deep down you know that your faithful friends are still alive somewhere close by. After all, they are strong as a rock and light as a feather (better to be a feather than a rock if you have to swim ashore).

Tempest is an action/RPG game set in the charming Pirate era, where you take control of a ship and its crew. You will explore the sea and battle with or against pirates and other factions (9 in total). Gather as many goods and gold as you can because your journey will not be easy, and you will not be without a scratch to you.

Reach ports and you will be able to repair your ship in case you could not dodge effectively those small projectiles named “Cannonballs”, “Bar shots”, “Shrapnel’s”, “Mortars” and others. Buy well-needed medicines for your wounded crew, ammunition, hire new pirate to your crew or even give them a bit of training (you need experience points which you earn in battle) so they can be a little bit more efficient during battle. Upgrade your vessel hull (can’t upgrade everywhere though) or add an artefact to it but first you have to earn it in battle. Another aspect I really like is the customisation of your boat, add signs on your sails and flags, defence structure, skull and others on your bow… Fabulous, I reckon I was a pirate in my previous life.

Movements in battle are really simple, you just use WASD on your keyboard. W and S are for the speed of your ship: you can choose to have your sail fully open (100%), half open (50%) or just stand still and get probably get hammered! A and D will be the keys to steer your boat either left or right.  You will be able to choose the precision of your shots, but it will take you longer to reload your cannon. If you prefer to get 80% chance of hitting your enemies it will take you 4.9 seconds to reload against 2.2 seconds if you choose 30% chance of hitting your target. Sometimes, it is only a couple of seconds that determine success or defeat. The targeting system is like a V on each side of your ship. The point of the V will be on each side of your ship and that will give you the angle of your firing range. Keep your enemies in sight within the V and all you have to do is fire your cannons. The closer you are from your enemies, the better chance to hit them hard! Oh.. I nearly forgot, you might even encounter interesting sea creatures like the “Mighty Kraken” or other small sea beasts.

Positives:
~~~~~~~

-	Good graphics
-	Good and easy combat system
-	Good ship customisation
-	Good  management content in port (trading, hiring, etc)

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~

-	Don’t have an option to start a new game. You will have reset and exit the game.
-	No achievement / Trading cards (early access)

Well, I am very impressed with this game so far. I truly can’t wait to see the final version! This game is a jewel in the making!

8.9/10

Early Access Review

Tempest is an Early Access naval combat game that focuses on ship customization, set in a vast world with elements of strategy and RPG.

In Tempest you'll play the captain of a ship who roams the mighty seas is search of wondrous treasures, destroying any who dare to cross him. Although still an Early Access title, Tempest has a lot of content to keep you playing including a large open world for you to explore at your leisure, multiple quest lines, factions and combat opportunities, ship customization such as weapons, colours, your sails and figurehead, and various mobs such as pirates, sharks and kraken (so I've heard). You can choose to live the pirates life with just you and your crew or find an alliance with one of the various factions you'll encounter throughout the world. You're welcome to plunder your way to riches or try the simple life of a sea merchant trading loot for gold both are viable options, all the while enjoying the rich graphics the game has to offer.

You start with just you and your ship and a quest that guides you to a close port to get you started. Once there you'll find a few quests, maybe a crew member and you have a chance to explore the port interface a little and see the options such as hiring and distributing your team, ship customization, available quests and traders.  Every port belongs to a faction and you can see the faction flag beside before you dock your ship. You'll make alliances and enemies with these factions and that'll affect which ports will be peaceful and hostile towards you. There are various ports dotted all around the world that you'll have the chance to find either being guided by quests, or just as you roam.
You can move your ship in one of two ways, the first being the map screen. On this screen you can simply draw the route you want your ship to travel in. Any ships you might encounter along the way will appear as a small pop-up and you can choose whether or not to switch to the other interface and engage. The second way to travel is in the 3D mode where you actually control your ship the same way you do whilst in combat. The 3D mode is much more immersive and gives you the feeling of actually sailing on the oceans. If you zoom right in you can even drive in first person mode from the ships wheel which, if you can ignore the rigid crew member sprites, feels awesome. Whilst controlling your ship directly you can choose to play with your camera free or locked, switching between the two can make combat a lot easier.

Combat in Tempest is real time and consists of you choose which attack you want to do and which side of the ship you want to fire from. Different attacks have different ranges and different reload times but also increased or decreased accuracy depending on the attack you are doing. You can also choose which cannonballs you want to fire and this will determine the damage dealt to hostile ships. Though I enjoy the combat I don't understand why there is a chance to miss if I am 100% aiming at the ship in question. This doesn't work well with real time combat and I think the combat mechanics in game could do with a little bit of a rework. As you take hits your ship will lose some of it's health and over time your crew members will take damage and become wounded stopping them from being active at their posts lowing the overall efficiency of your ship. The more damage you take the more chance of your crew members dying completely and your ship sinking. Once combat is over you can loot all fallen ships (even those from factions you're allied with) which will be one of your main sources of income. If you sink after taking too much damage you won't die or get a game over, you'll respawn at a nearby friendly port but will have lost a significant amount of your wealth so sometimes a retreat is recommended or even just scavenging off of battles early on like I did.

Despite Tempest being fantastic in terms of gameplay the lack of a tutorial is something which hinders the game massively. There is very little that is explained to you and it did take me around three restarts before I felt I had a firm grip on what I was meant to be doing. Combat is almost impossible to learn without being sunk a few times and can become very frustrating. Also distributing your crew is never fully explained alongside what is affected by 'efficiency'. Things like this could be explained a lot easier by some text when you hover over options or icons but there is nothing currently. Right now Tempest desperately needs some tooltips. On the forums the developer has mentioned this is coming soon so I'll update this when that update is out.

Tempest manages to satisfy all of your needs whilst playing and offers a large amount of content already for an Early Access game. Despite lacking in a tutorial once you've figured things out the gameplay itself is very fun and immersive at times. Steam is lacking in good quality games of the Pirate genre and I think Tempest fills the spot perfectly.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Introduction
Avast, me hearties! Are ye longing for the bygone days of wooden sailing ships ruling the ocean waves? Do ye crave the tang of salty sea air? Are ye jest unable to wait for weevils in yer bread to tickle the stubs of yer rotting teeth? Do ye long for the gentle touch of Scurvy as it sneakily weakens yer body and soul? Would ye give anything for a chance to see the mighty Kraken?  Well look ye no further landlubber. Tempest is set in the age of pirates. Ye command thee a small ship with an equally small crew as ye set off on yer high seas adventures. Ye don’t have to be a pirate though if ye don’t want to be. Pirates are but one of the factions that are willing to have ye fly their colours. The majority of the gameplay takes place on yer ship as ye quest around between the various islands getting into mostly optional scuffles as ye sail around.

Gameplay
In Tempest you are a captain of a fledgling pirate ship searching for your lost crew. Your main goal is to gain the wealth needed to upgrade your ship and keep it out of Davy Jones’ locker. You amass wealth however you like. You can be the scourge of the sea known as a pirate or live the respectable life of a trader. You might even become a pirate hunter. You are free to choose but if you cross a faction too many times, you will become their enemy.

Flags help to show who you are. Decorative flags make you look spiffier, factional ones show where your loyalties lay. You begin with a Pirate and a Merchant flag. Leaving the pirate flag equipped when you join a battle will automatically represent you as the Pirate faction. The same goes if you have another faction’s flag equipped. If you are flying the Merchant flag, you will join your allies to rally against the pirate menace. If you go against a faction too much, you will quickly find yourself unwelcome in any of that factions ports. On the flip side, your Pirate buddies will see you as a mighty pirate and new quests will unlock for that faction.

Controlling your ship is simple in both the 2D map mode and in the 3D high seas mode. While in map mode, simply click where you want to go and the ship will set sail but it follows the course without deviation. You could ram an island en-route. There is a better way to set your course. Left click and hold it down to then draw the route you want your ship to take. The map is accurate in that it has the authentic dullness of maps from the by-gone days. The high seas mode is where the game really shines. The highly detailed ships are seen at sea complete with crew. The oceans look amazing and the ambient weather and diurnal cycle just make this mode look breathtaking. The controls are as easy as in map mode. Press forward for faster and backward to slow. Left and right to turn and that’s it. Use your spyglass to see what you are up against. The spyglass has a really cool effect on your screen that gives the feeling you are actually looking though one.

Let me tell you a story. I had barely started the game when I decided to visit the various ports to see if I could find ships for sale and to see what I would need to purchase one. I battled a few ships on my travels while flying the Jolly Roger. I then encountered a fort that didn’t want me to dock in their town and attacked my ship. That was when I first encountered the monster. The malevolent Kraken attacked my ship! The Kraken’s tentacles began reaching up both sides of my ship in a furious attempt to pull me down into a watery grave in the briny deep. I’d love to say that I became more infamous than the Dread Pirate Roberts that day and won my freedom, but sadly I cannot make that claim. The combined fire of the fort and the Kraken was too much and my ship sank beneath the churning waves.

Sinking in this game is not the end. You lose most of your belongings and wealth though, so it is a wise idea to unload goods to your warehouse before heading out. Eventually I was able to afford a bigger ship with better guns and parts all around. I had a good crew and became a mighty pirate known only as G. Threepwood.

Combat in the game is straight forward. Your ship has arcs for your cannons and once your arc lines up with the enemy hull you can open fire. If you hold off your trigger finger for a moment, your shot will gain in accuracy. You can select the type of cannonballs you want to use and the reload speed and accuracy in which they will fire. The more accurate you want to be, the less firing arc you will have and the longer it will take between shots. Next, you have to figure out how you want to win this fight. You can go broadsides to broadsides if you are so inclined. I personally found starting out with a little bit of cowardice… I mean tactical retreating is a good way to get your wealth flowing in. Once I had longer ranged cannons I was actually able to sink enemy ships without them scratching my paint so I was quite happy about that. I admit that taking long-range potshots on the enemy is expensive in terms of cannon ball expenditures so I changed my cannons to short range and decided to kill the crew instead. I read a comment by the developer that ship capturing is something that is being implemented. Currently sailing close to the enemy and boarding only allows you to get supplies. One day I hope to capture an enemy ship and keep it as my own. For now, I will simply have to buy my ships and upgrade them myself.

The ability to upgrade is simple. You find parts you want and dock at a port. The port is straight forward and mostly the same everywhere you go. You see several icons to choose from and once you select the one you are looking for you will be taken to the respective screen. Here is where you buy and sell, hire crew, take on new quests, and retrofit your ship with parts you have acquired. Artifacts can also be added to your ship to give you special abilities. These artifact abilities help to separate Tempest from other similar nautical games and add a whole new level of fun to the game. Not all stores sell the same items so you will likely have to dock a few times before you find what you want. This is where the factions really start to come into play.

Joining a faction has perks besides just having a safe place to dock. Each faction has a joining bonus that you can’t seem to acquire elsewhere so you might want to visit each of the factions to see what they have to offer. Even if a faction hates you, it isn’t the end of the world. You can still equip their flag to suck up to them and eventually they will pardon you.

Considering Tempest is still in Early Access right now, it’s actually very good as it is. The developer is actively supporting the game and listening to the community. If you want your change to help shape the game, you might want to get it now. There is even a new area being worked on as we speak! Additionally, multiplayer is working already and is quite interesting. I have not played multiplayer as much as I have the single player so I can’t comment too much on it but from the looks of it, the game will really come to life if you play in multiplayer.

Pros:Visually the game looks great considering its low system requirements
The sound is suitable for the game and works quite well to aid in the immersion
Simple controls
Re-playable without getting boring due to Faction system
Weather effects that go beyond just visuals. Some Artifacts only work when it rains.
Mythological creatures

Cons:

Unfinished. It’s in Early Access so the game doesn’t have all the bells and whistles and polish yet. It stands pretty well as it is though so that is no reason to ignore it.
Currently lacks a proper/complete tutorial. Took me about an hour, with multiple restarts to really figure everything out.

- The waves kind of clip through all the things.  People can shoot through each other and the environment.  Not terrible, but sometimes when I see it I can't unsee it.
- Can get to be a bit of a grind trying to score 9000 coins for an upgrade when you get 150-250 per battle at the start

Overall, it's fine.  If you like naval simulations this may be too basic for you, but it has a place as a quick and easy age of sail-type game.  If you can grab it on sale, even better!
